On 1/20/06, Robert Lucente <rlucente@...> wrote:
>
> "I know that =
some will argue that I should
> use more mocks to reduce dependancies"
>
> =
It depends on the situation. Sometimes creating a mock involves a lot of
> =
effort.
>
> It seems like we have 3 situations ?
>
> 1) Run all the tests i=
n any order
>
> 2) Run these x tests in this y order and stop as soon as yo=
u hit the first
> failure.
>
> 3) Tests that combine 1) and 2).
>
> I am a =
newbie and haven't read/studied the doco carefully. So, I don't
> know
> ho=
w easy it is to do 2).
>
> "value in the concept of dependency"
>
> Definit=
ely !


Good to see this recognized.

A typical example is Web tests:  what=
's the point of running a hundred tests
exercising servlets if the Web serv=
er failed to start?  It also helps for
the diagnostic:  instead of telling =
the user "101 tests failed", you can
tell them "1 test failed, 100 tests we=
re skipped".

TestNG lets you define dependencies on methods (which is frag=
ile) and on
groups, which is much more flexible since adding test methods t=
o groups
doesn't force you to adjust your dependencies.


On 1/20/06, Mark =
Levison <mlevison@...> wrote:On 1/20/06, Robert
Lucente <rlucente@pip=
eline.com> wrote:
>
> 2) Run these x tests in this y order and stop as soon=
 as you hit the first
> failure.


All I want with Dependancy is run test x=
 before all the tests that depend on
it. If test x passes then run the othe=
r tests in any order. If test x fails
then don't run those tests. I believe=
 this is called partial ordering.


On 1/20/06, Mark Levison <mlevison@gmai=
l.com> wrote:
>
>
> All I want with Dependancy is run test x before all the=
 tests that depend
> on
> it. If test x passes then run the other tests in =
any order. If test x
> fails
> then don't run those tests. I believe this i=
s called partial ordering.


Exactly.

Dependencies typically represent a s=
mall portion of your tests:  most of
them can usually be run in any order.
=
